nodes.text: Lexicon-based sentiment analysis (Hedonometer) systematically differs from machine-learning based sentiment analysis (Azure) due to individual lexical entries, and identifying those outlier words explains score differences across domains
We compare Hedonometer and Microsoft Azure Text Analytics sentiment scores on texts from four domains to identify lexical entries causing score differences
We model differences between Hedonometer and Azure sentiment scores using linear regression with Hedonometer lexical entries as independent variables and examine significance (p-values)
Datasets comprise over 150,000 English texts from four domains: Finance, News, Social Media (tweets), and IMDB reviews; Hedonometer lexicon coverage differs by domain

Hedonometer assigns context-free happiness scores to 10,222 words from Mechanical Turk ratings on a nine-point scale and computes document sentiment by frequency-weighted average normalized by document length
Azure outputs sentiment scores in the interval 0 (negative) to 1 (positive) and is used as the target standard in comparisons
Hedonometer words appearing per domain: Finance 966, News 274, Social media 1,886, IMDB 2,673, total distinct across domains 3,810 out of 10,222
Regression p-values identify words with smallest p-values whose Hedonometer weights differ most from Azure and words with largest p-values whose interpretations align between systems
We limited analysis to Hedonometer words present in at least three of the four domains to test consistency of outlier status across domains

Score-difference distributions: Finance and News show approximate agreement in mid-range with few extreme differences; Social media shows greater differences; IMDB reviews show extreme differences with few agreed scores due to Hedonometer's narrower range
There are no major universal outlier words across domains; only a few words (example: 'mom') appear with extreme p-values in more than one domain

Spearman correlations between Hedonometer ranking and p-value ranking are weak and vary by domain (Finance -0.1126, News -0.1206, Social media 0.2949, IMDB 0.3300), indicating weak association between a word's Hedonometer happiness and its importance in score differences

Because Hedonometer covers only a fraction of lexicon words present in domain texts and has context-free scores, word importance depends on domain and no single set of lexicon weight changes will align Hedonometer to Azure across domains
Limitations: restricting analysis to words present in datasets (3,810 of 10,222) and using linear regression with many independent variables raises multiple hypothesis testing concerns
Practical implication: adjustments to Hedonometer lexical weights are unlikely to materially change overall sentiment outputs and consistent use of a tool is preferable to cross-tool comparisons

Future work: analyze texts selected by presence of specific Hedonometer words for greater coverage, apply multiple hypothesis testing correction or use non-parametric ML models to assess feature importance
